page.title: 06OVER WYRESDALE: BEEF CATTLE
page.content: Farms in this area which do not have dairy herds concentrate instead on breeding and rearing beef cattle which, like the sheep, are sent to the auction market at Lancaster. The dams are a cross between Herefords and Friesians. Beef sucklers are produced by crossing these dams with Charolais. Bulls are kept on some farms but artificial insemination is also used. Farmers aim to have suckler calves born in January as these will be old enough to turn out to grass in April and will not need concentrates. They are usually sold for finishing in October weighing 7-8 cwts and any not up to weight standard are brought inside to feed. On the higher, less sheltered farms calves may not be born until April and will be fed inside on hay or silage and concentrates during the autumn prior to Christmas sales.
